name: FEZ
description: Gomez is a 2D creature living in a 2D world. Or is he? When the existence of a mysterious 3rd dimension is revealed to him, Gomez is sent out on a journey that will take him to the very end of time and space. Use your ability to navigate 3D structures from 4 distinct classic 2D perspectives.

Latest graphics drivers are required to maximize OpenGL feature compatibility.

Latest graphics drivers are required to maximize OpenGL feature compatibility.

reviews.review_text: Note: This review is for FEZ, not Phil Fish.  Acclaimed as one the best indie videogames ever made, FEZ is a puzzle platformer in a 3D space composed of 4 2D planes. I agree that this game is nearly perfect. It's fun to play. The controls are okay. The music is cool. The art is brilliant. And there are good designed puzzles. And the best part is it's difficulty: in this game you need to collect 32 normal cubes and 32 anti-cubes, among other things. The normal cubes are easy to find, and to beat the game you only need 32 cubes. So, if you're not very good with puzzle games, you can beat this game. Since it has (almost) an open world style, if you get stuck you can just keep moving ahead, instead of being stuck forever. The anti-cubes are harder, but some are easier to get than others. But getting them all is a real challenge. And there are also 3 red cubes, which are extremely hard to find. So, this is a game for everyone. I think it has the right lenght, but it can be annoying sometimes, for example when you need to backtrack. This is definitely one of the best games i ever played, a true masterpiece in almost every way. Buy it now (on sale is even better).
Love Fish or hate him, only a cynically biased person could resist praising this game. It's a masterpiece.

Short answer: this is a masterpiece.   Long answer: it is sad that most people would turn down this amazing experience just because they care much more about the hate they feel towards its developer, whose opinions and points of view got taken way out of context by the media. Those people miss an excellent opportunity to be immersed in an unique platformer whose environment is breathtaking and truly puzzling. I'm so happy I discovered this work of art and I would do anything to make its sequel see the light of day. But I guess good things come in small packages, and Fez offers more than enough.

Another quaint puzzle platformer that takes a revisionist lens to the retro games of a bygone era. I'm sure everyone's tired of them. But, you should get over it and play Fez. I can't imagine why you haven't already. You've seen all the praise right? Well if you are holding back from playing Fez to look cool, or because you hate Phil Fish, really, you are only hurting yourself.  If you have an ounce of interest in puzzles or platformers, or puzzle platformers, congratulations! You should own this, you should play it and figure everything out. The aesthetics are exremely well done, but i'm not going to dwell on them. Fez's key mechanic is perspective shifting. You are a 2D character that can rotate which face of a 3D world you are on. I am not going to pretend this mechanic is brand new (Ortho comes to mind, though there is probably an older example), but it is done extremely well and makes for some very interesting puzzles. On top of the dizzying perspective switching, there is also a whole language you have to learn to solve some of the puzzles.  The ending is also one of the most beautiful things i've seen and the new game plus features one of the best punch lines out there. It is an unforgettable game that is bursting with charm, challenge, and some other praise that starts with 'ch'.

Just stop and enjoy the sights and sounds. That's the vibe I get from this. Most of this game is very well done and fun. The pixel art is finely done and matches almost flawlessly with the soundtrack. It's a short game taking me just under 10 hours to get just about 100% done. That may be longer than average since I really enjoyed the art and sounds of the game and would find myself drifting off just admiring them.   However I am not going to learn a fake box language that is my only gripe. Seriously the only one. Everything else is great.
A small and unique little game.  Also, rip Fish, thanks for the game.

Hours in and new mechanics are still being thrown at you. If you even remotely get any enjoyment out of puzzles, this game will push your mind to its limit. Not to mention the phenominal aesthetic (the creator spent 5 years developing this game, even going as far as throwing out and completely redoing the graphics because they weren't exactly as he imagined), the sunsets and the sunrises, the music, the creatures you find running around this amazing world; it's all perfect. Any screenshots or videos you watch of this game don't do the experience you will have exploring this world justice. On this topic, DON'T get turned off from buying this game because of anything you may have heard about the creator, because in reality that has nothing to do with this masterpiece.
Fresh idea, fantastic background with an unbelievable quality of pixel art. Masterpiece. 8.5/10

This game is really simple. But simple in the right way! A simple innovation in a consolidated gameplay will open a new dimention in how you can approach problems and puzzles. Secrets can be slightly frustrating btw. Neverthless, it has one of the best cost/ratio I've ever seen.

I've been playing this off and on for a few days. Very relaxing light puzzler with a fun game mechanic, good music, very nice pixel art. My only real gripe is that most of the puzzles are pretty easy and you don't really feel like a genius for figuring them out. I would still recommend it.

A phenomenal puzzle game with a great aesthetic and a cute twist that turns just another platformer into an incredible experience.  This game, and particularly its author, has had its share of drama. Personally, I feel that the fact that people in the gaming community drove the game's creator away, made him hate making games, is a massive blow to the medium.  This is absolutely a game you must try out. The gameplay is solid, the art style is beautiful, the mechanics are unique, and the easter eggs and allusions are on-point.

This game is incredible. Please ignore the issues sorruounding it's creator as they are not worth focusing on when there is an incredible game behind it all. This game is a one-of-a-kind original piece of art, that is the only way to discribe it. This is a puzzle game which is enough to turn many people away but it has an amazing twist to it: 'Dimension bending' as I like to call it (Althought they probably have an offical name for it). 'Dimension bending' is extreemle difficult to explain and I recomend that you watch a video of some gamplay of FEZ to see how it works. The art style is a beutiful modernised 8 bit which makes me never want to stop looking at it. As a result of the simplistic, yet amazing, graphics, the game runs easily on most system and is loved by many because of this. The sound track for this game is truley mesmorising. It has been created in such a way that it really feels like it belongs in the world that FEZ is set in. You can get a good few hours out of this game (I have not yet completed it on this acount, I have on my other) and is well worth the £7 (Or your equivelant) which is being Charged. In summary, this game is a masterpiece, something which will hopefully inspire amazing games in the future, which diserves credit. Sadly I say that the developer deserves credit for making this (Although I know he is a prick). You as the potential purchaser have a choice: buy an amazing game and don't buy a few pacets of sweets as a subsitute or don't buy it and leave without an amazing 10 or so hours of your life.
Great game but the levels sometimes feel like the same thing.

Before I begin, let's get something out of the way - yes, you have probably heard that the game's designer, Phil Fish, is some kind of egotistical crazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (or something along those lines)... Regardless of whether that is true or not, don't let it deter you from playing this game. All that extraneous stuff aside, FEZ, as a game, is the real deal.   You play as Gomez, a little dude who lives a nice peaceful life in a 2D world. That is, until about 5 minutes into the game, when he is given a gift - the titular fez - which opens up a whole new world to him. Literally. The fez allows Gomez to rotate his 2D world at any time, to reveal the previously unseen 3rd dimension. For example, there may be a platform that is too far away to jump to, but rotating the world 90 degrees shifts the perspective such that the platform appears to be much closer. You can then jump to it and rotate the world back to where it was, or in any of the other 3 directions. This is the most basic example of the gameplay, but it's also just the beginning. The sheer number of cool ways this one simple mechanic alone has an effect on puzzle-solving and exploration is amazing. It's just really fun to explore and figure things out. Your main goal is to collect a series of special cubes, which are scattered throughout a pretty large world. Some cubes are found intact, but others require collecting smaller cube bits first to create a full cube. That's really all there is to the game. But just saying it that way is a disservice. The puzzles you have to solve to find all these cubes range from simple to - forgive the pun - truly outside-the-box. This is because there is more going on in FEZ than appears on the surface. A major part of solving the game's mysteries involves figuring out various codes outside of the game itself (such as deciphering the number system and alphabet, scanning QR codes, and more). So not only will you need a controller to play this game, but a pad and pencil as well. The game can be completed without finding all of the cubes (and actually has to be the first time through), but in order to get the most out of it, a little bit of extra effort is needed... though I suppose you could also just look up the solutions to some of the more effort-intensive puzzles online. I wouldn't blame you. There were only a few things that brought the game down for me a little bit. The big one was the confusing and mostly ineffectual map. The game world is huge, like really huge, and is connected by a crazy number of doors. It was very difficult to keep track of where you are and how to get somewhere else. And while there is a sort of quick-travel system available, it wasn't really implemented well. The map screen is also overly complicated and buggy. Finally, some of the puzzles I felt stepped a little too far in terms of either their obscure solutions or plain tediousness. But aside from these few minor missteps, FEZ is very much worth playing, especially if you are into platformers, retro-looking graphics, solving codes/mysteries, or games that involve collecting things. Oh, and the music is pretty amazing too. All in all, FEZ is a pretty outstanding game, and well-deserving of all the accolades it has received.  Final Grade: A-  Technical notes: You are definitely going to want to play this game using an Xbox360 controller, or equivalent. It was designed to be played with a controller and I can't even imagine how it could even work well otherwise. Some puzzles even require having a controller to figure out. So, just something to keep in mind.
Very interesting concept and creativity. One of the most unique games out there.

FEZ is a fun 2D world which you can actually rotate to see the entirety of each level. Rotating a level will create new paths you can navigate to progess through the map. The game is fun, albeit a bit complicated. It's one of those games you probably won't be able to finish without a guide - I know I wouldn't have been able. Overall, it's a fun game that's worth playing at least once.

Great Game. Goes back to the roots of exloration and captivating puzzles. Brings back back to old school games where I enjoyed exploring and solving puzzles on my own without the use of guides. Only complaint I have is the lenght. I wish the game was longer.

This game, with its beautiful art style, fantastic art style and great concept, has captured my heart. I love this game 6/5. One complaint: the secrets really are very secret. If you don't want to spend more than ten hours in this game, you better find a guide.
A riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma, and possibly the best game of the 21st Century so far... I want to erase my brain so I can re-play it from scratch!
With its groundbreaking gameplay, FEZ is one of the best indie games of 2013. If you like puzzling, full of secrets, and, most of all, singular games, this is the one for you.
The atomosphere of this game is what makes it truly special. 8/10
great game but better with a gamepad

Fez is a very casual platformer with an adventure game feel. The game is pretty easy to finish and there are no enemies to fight, but there are also a lot of fun little secrets and puzzles for those who want to try collecting everything. Cute graphics with some nice variety between locations, great music, lots of fun.

A masterful platformer that is simply addictive. It's jam-packed with some incredible features, including four third-dimensional perspectives to play from, tons of items to collect, and lots of challenging puzzles to conquer. Great replay value. For a platformer, this is simply beautiful.

This game is amazing. If you enjoy games like Kyntt, then this is a must have. It's very suggestive, and it has a wide varieties of puzzles. I was sceptical about this game at the beginning, but then I changed my mind immediately
An excellent puzzle game if you ignore the fact that the creator is a pretentious jerk.
This is a great game to play while watching Breaking Bad on Netflix. I really like the puzzles and the atmosphere in the game.  Just wish that the dev was just as amazing as the game.
s'butiful
I bought this when Summer Sale. and this game is so absolutely great. Combine 3D + 2D world puzzle with Cute main character. Try it

Fez is a retro game. Fez is an indie game. Fez is a 2D platformer, yet all of these descriptions barely scratch the surface of what makes this game so great.  This is a smart game. It is ingeniously designed and an absolute joy to play all the way through. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys very involved and challenging puzzles where the answers are not always clear. This game will ask of you not only your platforming skills and drive to explore, but also your ability to pay attention to small details and be able to break ciphers almost entirely on your own. I had to have a piece of paper beside me while I played so I could write down codes and keys to solving ciphers, but I found it to be extremely fun and rewarding. If you're not into that sort of stuff, this game may not be your thing.  Each area is brilliantly designed, with visuals that are never an eyesore. Each zone has its own style and personality, and almost every room has a secret for an astute player. The soundtrack is always fitting, if not especially riveting, though I'm sure you'll find a track or two that you'll love. The game pays homage to classic games of the 8-bit era, with a few nuggets of nostalgia strewn here and there for you old Nintendo fans out there.  Overall, Fez an exceptional game, though it is not without its flaws. I run a fairly powerful PC, surely powerful enough to run a visually simplistic game like Fez, yet I had problems with screen flikering, a stripe of glitchiness through the middle of my screen, and phantom graphics throughout my entire playthrough. It was bothersome, but I could ignore it. It's a fairly common problem from what I've read, and it can be solved easily, so just be aware. Some puzzles were genuinely difficult or frustrating, namely the clock tower anti-cubes and the infamous black monolith. You will almost certainly need a guide for these puzzles.  Other than those relatively minor gripes, the game is fantastic. I'd recommend playing with a controller if possible, but the experience shouldn't be any worse if playing with a controller isn't possible. I'd give this game a final score of 9.5/10.

One of the best games I've ever played. It is challenging and that can be a little bit of a bummer but if you stick with it and really thinking about what they are trying to get you to accomplish it really isn't so bad. I HIGHLY recommend this game.
Buy this game. Play this game.
Everyone must own this game.
great game but better with a gamepad
was upset that this entire game is actually just a elaborate Doctor Who reference
... probably amongst the top 10 platformers of all time ... I ♥♥♥♥ you not ...

In Phil Fish's Austism simulator 2012 you play as Gomez, an unemployed mexican worker tasked with mowing the golden lawn, but you have to get all the crack rocks before you are allowed to mow the lawn, upon completion of finding these crack rocsk you are tasked with watching all 7 seasons of my little pony, after this gut-wrenching trial you discover that your wife and 17 children have been abducted by the swedish mafia, Led by Notch, in order to get them back you decide to go through a trial no phagget has gone through before, the hall of a million D1ckz awaits but before you enter that door, you have to pay the 2.49 on-disk DLC fee, after completing this hall of seamen and phagg0try, you are forced to show your documents to the police, but OH NO, you left them in your other jeans, so after being sent back to mexico where you belong you realize that you are coming down from that acid you dropped three days ago, at this point you realize something that you though you knew from the beggining, Gomez is Notch, Shrek is love, shrek is life
It's more art rather than a game. But it sure is pretty, along with a soothing soundtrack.
Awesome game, nice art style, cool music, and overall awesome game 10/10

I went into this game expecting a bad platformer (Respawning right where you are? You can't have any challenge with that!). What I ended up finding is a puzzle game, and a pretty unique one.  Rather than having a set of rooms that you solve through using the quirky 3D mechanic, it's actually about exploring the world, gathering clues to understand how the various artifacts you find work. Somewhat similar to an in-game ARG that you can solve yourself.  Some puzzles can get complicated and the game sometimes expects you to make some pretty long leaps in logic. But once you figure it out after thinking about it for a while, you feel very clever and it can also bring light to another mystery elsewhere in the world that was getting you stumped earlier, which is quite rewarding and makes you want to go check it out immediately.  The ambiance is also a big part of the game, with it's pleasing atmospheric soundtrack and the wildly varying environments that you discover. This reinforces the whole 'exploring the world' aspect of the game, and is very successful. You can also go look for deeper meanings to the implied events that happen in the game. I personally was very content just looking for puzzles and smelling the roses, but it's certainly there for people who like it, and it adds to the overall mysterious ambiance.  In the end, I was pleasantly surprised, and quickly found myself caught in the mystery-solving, ending up with a few pages of scribbles and a lot of screenshots taken as notes. If you like investing yourself into ARG-like puzzles you'll certainly get caught like me.    Now I feel sorta bummed out for Fez 2.

Ok, everybody knows that the creator of this game is a really bad person, but in this review i'll only talk about the game's undeniable quality. Fez is an amazing experience! It goes beyond the game, and you'll feel like you have been transported into a dreamy and surreal world, while playing. It's relaxing, yet somehow challenging. I have to warn you , though... The game is mostly puzzle/exploration driven, and sometimes it's quite cryptic, so you'll need a bit of patience, but then you'll be rewarded with one of the best games ever made. The graphics are something gorgeous! It seems to look like an 8 bit game, but it actually isn't. It's much richer and the game is actually 3D, while mantaining the charm of the 8bit graphics, with the added value of amazing color contrasts and gradients, impossible to achieve in the 8bit era. Sound is amazing aswell, incredibly relaxing and evocative! I also suggest getting the game's soundtrack.  A highly recommended game!
Brilliantly charming game, arguably the best puzzle-platformer I've played.
Great game, but do not even bother 100%ing without a guide (or spending twenty years of your life on it).
This game will blow your mind.
'Seems like I cant reach there.' *switches view* 'Oh, I am actually there.'  We need more games like these. But map is still frustrating.

The design and graphisms are great. It really is an ADVENTURE with a huge world to explore. About that.... to solve the puzzles, the player needs to understand the world's cubic language and numerical system. Too much of a bother for just a videogame in my opinion. Just exploring was the best part.  In the 2D/3D platforming genre, I enjoyed Perspective much better.  Oh, I forgot to add that the PC port is not so great, it shows that the controls are adapted to a gamepad.

One of, if not, the best games I have ever had the pleasure of playing. It is simply beautiful in every way, the artwork is gorgeous, the gameplay is superb and the 2D/3D aspect is simply magnificent.

I love this game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys platforming, retro, indie, or puzzle games. The creative mechanic and fresh graphics with some poppy music as well as tough but still fun puzzles makes this one of my all time favorite video games. Even though I got it on sale, i'd say its worth 10$ if you have it.

Fez is a true one-hit wonder; that rare game that blows your mind and just keeps blowing it until the very end. A masterpiece in game-design and world-building, Fez takes this new concept and rolls with it through strange, beautiful worlds. It is a true tragedy that we won't see another game quite like it again, but that only makes Polytron's debut title shine brighter. A platformer that rewards experimentation and exploration with discovery and mystery, FEZ out-Nintendos Nintendo in just about every department. If you're at the least bit curious about this controversial title, I had fun with it. I'm sure you would too.

When I started the game I only wanted to have a quick look. When I learned about what makes the game really tick I wanted to refuse to force myself through all of this. But before I knew it, I was already sucked into it and eventually got all achievements. I'm not exactly sure how they did it, but it worked.  The experience around FEZ has multiple layers.  On the surface you have this cute and easy going, gimmicky Platformer that plays with optical illusions. Before I played it I had the impression you had to do a little more three-dimensional and logical thinking. But as it turned out, you only have to swap the perspective until you can progress. This layer is all about finding the way, spotting doors and traversal. In and of itself that is already quite engaging, because you have this rather vast world with multiple paths. Discovering all the rooms and places to complete the map is pretty fun, I think. You have warp gates and shortcuts to streamline it more but it is true, that you have to backtrack very often.  When it come to exploring, I am really impressed how they managed to tweak your navigation. You know, all these little conveniences everyone takes for granted. Almost every (major) screen has a distinguished element, like a landmark that you can see in the background or as preview that hovers in the air while you stand in front of a door. Some screens have a different color palette, that makes them easy to recognize. The map gives you all sorts of feedback. The warp gates show you the sky that is unique to certain areas so you know where they'll lead you. Also you can easily see which rooms you havn't visited yet because doors will stay open.  When you got enough collectibles, you can complete the storyline (if you wanna call it that). But after that, the game shows its true colors. You need to play the  new game +  mode to enjoy it to its fullest.  You see, FEZ is about secrets and hidden stuff, really. It would be undermining the point if I told you what it was. Let me say it more simple so you don't get overwhelmed by all the cryptic stuff: You need to look closely at your surroundings and watch out for signs in order to decipher codes. Most of these require you to write something down. Then you have to input key commands to communicate to the game that you solved the puzzle. But it gets even more complicated. You need to think laterally and meta for some of the other things. There is a number system, an alphabet and input symbols. Try to make them out by yourself. There are hints but nothing is spelled out for you.  I love the music and the animation.
Just mind blowing

PROS:  + satisfying & fun gameplay + really nice UI & menu + great puzzles + dimension shifting + new game+ + awesome pixelated visuals + tons of collectables to find   CONS:  - a couple of ridiculously hard not very logical puzzles - occassional ladder glitch (especially in the 'globe room') - occassional crash to desktop (twice in 13hrs of gameplay)   Comment:  I went into playing FEZ without expectations and after finishing it I have to say it was really incredible! Sometimes simple and easy, sometimes really hard (looking at you, rising lava level) but always fun. The '3D' shifting mechanism works really well and makes the game feel really unique and original. On top of that is a cool map of locations, each filled with either NPCs, collectables, puzzles or just platforms. It is hard to pinpoint what I like about this game so much but I guess it could be the way it lets you progress. While the floating cube gives you vague hints it is YOU who tries out which path to go. The only thing about the game logic that I disliked was the cryptic language and a couple of puzzles that were a bit too hard in the way that I had no idea what the game wanted from me. So, yes, I helped myself with a guide after collecting all that I could (which was most of the stuff). However other puzzles like vibrating controller hints were really cool and I loved them. The pixelated graphics are a nice touch, they fit the game really well too. Overall I can see the tremendous amount of time spent on making this game, it is AWESOME! So awesome that I am purchasing another copy (maybe via GoG) to support the developers. Result? You can either recommend FEZ or you have not played it.

This game is a MUST play. Delivering a puzzle game experience like none other, FEZ redefines the meaning of atmosphere gameplay. Not to mention the ABSOLUTELY stunning graphics & sound track  If you're an indie gamer like me, you'll find this game quite the journey, a true masterpiece in 'perspective-puzzles'. you'll find yourself the rewarding feeling of accomplishment each time you solve a problem  ~Have Fun~
Great puzzle game with a unique style of puzzle solving and and an awesome retro art stlye. Definitely worth the money.

I really enjoy this game! Simple, yet taxing to the brain, it really is a work of art. Through its vivid colors and music, the game gives every single different scene its own style and atmosphere. Often I just pause, and stare at the sunset, or the stars and admire the scene. Along with these admirable qualities, FEZ brings new and innovative ideas to the platforming and puzzle genres, which we will hopefully see in future games. Overall, this game gives a refreshing taste of the platformer and puzzle genres. In one sentence - FEZ really brings its pixels to life.

This is THE most immersive, fun, and difficult puzzle I've ever played in my life. I bought this game when it came out impulsively, like many game collectors on steam, and the experiences I've had with this far outweigh the money I spent on it. This game has some of the most mind-blowing, rage-inducing puzzles ever seen in any video game, but as the case is with any puzzle game, the gratification you get from solving the puzzle makes it all the worthwhile. The presentation of a 3D world from a 2D perspective is also an extremely cool concept, and makes platforming quite fun, and also spices up some of the already difficult puzzles :> I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys rage-inducing puzzles and little white people wearing fezes. As a gamer who has previously mostly only played FPSes, this game was an eye-opener for me. From the game design, platforming, puzzles, innovation, and even the soundtrack, this game is really a perfect 10 from every perspective (lel) for me.  Edit: THis game suck

FEZ is one of those games that feels random at first, but as the story progresses, you can't help but feel the cringe-worthy satisfaction of getting the scattered golden cubes one after another. The game lets you set the pace and execute different types of approach. Thus, the immensity of this cube-tastic game and the variety of puzzles, mazes, and other rage-inducing challenges that Gomez has to face, will pull you in to the cube-ception of this iterating world of FEZ.  The hours I've played may be deceiving *70% of the anti-cube goes to youtube videos and reading through unnecessary google results.* but the game will most likely be twice of the time I have done. However, the challenges and the different patterns of mazes in each section are all beautifully designed and in each section, it feels like you are in a completely different zone. My personal description may seem unrealistic and far-fetched, but it is up for you whether you'd accept it or ignore the game's mind-blowing experience. Despite the decision you have made, FEZ is a hell of a game nonetheless.
This is my favorite game EVER. It's full of secrets, metaphors and fun platforming. One of the best indie games ever, go get it!

I didn't stop playing from the moment I began - very addictive platformer. The puzzles and level design are mind boggling, and no one's going to read this anyway, so I will confess that I have been drinking my housemate's juice.

I found FEZ very charming. It's a bit tedious compared to other platformers, but has lots of atmosphere and mystery to make up for it. Its main mechanic is rotation. The world is a three-dimensional space 'flattened' into whatever side you're looking at, and to progress you can turn it around. The platforming is fairly trite - the level design uses that rotation system very cleverly, but there's lots of waiting for the slow protagonist to walk somewhere. And surviving a fall makes you lose more progress than dying, which is very annoying. On the other hand, the game world is lovingly designed. The relaxing, beautiful and mysterious atmosphere will make you smile and the dragged-out platforming actually helps you take in the details.  The world is filled with mysteries and cryptography puzzles, which are optional and vague but very satisfying to solve.  I recommend this game for its beautiful ambience and strange puzzles that may please fans of games like La-Mulana and Antichamber. Be aware of its slow pace and focus on atmosphere over action though.

FEZ is a relaxing pixely puzzle platformer, where you get to navigate a daedalic map system looking for mysterious cubes. The twist to classic platforming is that you can actually rotate the map left and right to reveal hidden areas and climbing points, while the puzzles include a lot of code breaking. FEZ looks like any other cute puzzle platformer at first glance, but it can be surprisingly addictive in its depth. Some puzzles are pretty hard to crack and you can find hints on the backstory while exploring. Even though this game is probably not for everyone, I feel it is at least worth your consideration. Playing with a controller is strongly recommended.

Some of the most romanticised events of history are those of great explorers and their struggle against unforeseen difficulty: searing heat, freezing cold, malaria and navigation over great seas and jungles in search of unknown knowledge and treasure.  In Fez, it is revealed to you, as a two-dimensional creature that your reality actually has three dimensions, each with two-dimensional creatures living unbeknownst to each other. The ability is granted by the namesake fez which he wears at all times after the opening sequence. Perspective based platforming is well-explored, but Fez still comes over as fresh and charming, with its extensive and beautiful 3D pixel art on all sides.  As the owner of the fez, you are charged with assembling cubes from pieces scattered across the dimensions in order to repair the universe. The game truly is expansive, with many unique art styles across the many sectors and subsectors, each forming a minimum of 4 separate 2D platform sections as you rotate the camera in 3D.  I was disappointed in Fez. I feel like the game could have been so much more, but it is also clear that the creators had a very different vision to what I would have hoped. Fez is about exploring, and that is  all it is about , there are no enemies, or bosses or quests or miniquests or upgrades or pickups, or shops or anyone to talk to. The game is an endless search for cubes, and though one or two new mechanics are introduced in this search, they all felt tedious and simple, including: The lever which you have to rotate your camera in 3D to turn every time you want to use it, the platforms in that one hub world that rotate irritatingly in 3D, forcing you to rotate the camera as they rotate or jump like you’re trying to defeat Air Man’s vanishing bricks; and the most common ‘puzzle’ in secrets, look up and translate the alien symbols into English (which, by the way also describe the Xbox 360 controls and not the PC controls, so you always have to look them up).  If the creators’ intention was to question the reason you were searching for cubes at all, they did a very good job in heavily instilling that feeling in me. At the beginning I made an exhaustive search for cubes in each area, making sure to find every last one, assuming that somehow by collecting these I would be in a better position in the other worlds. But the cubes only unlock  more worlds , where you can collect more cubes  but for what?   Travelling between worlds is a tedious and irritating process, as there is no ‘fast travel’ in the game. If you, like I did, exhaust the world of cubes before you left, you must move through these empty worlds, solving all the puzzles you did before, backwards to get back to where you were so that you can explore the game’s branching paths. These worlds are extremely extensive and still require extensive precision jumping, rotating and thinking just to get through them. Some 'hub worlds' have portals, but you still have to reach them from whatever backwater dimension you were in.  The best comparison to another game I can make is The Machine         YouTube™ Video:  Knytt Stories: The Machine playthrough to the normal ending on normal

As far as I've played so far, I love it. I find it unique and creative, as not many games out there are both 2D and 3D. Navigation through worlds is a little bit frustrating as well, as you have to constantly refer back to the map in order to see the next screenshot of the area you need to go to next to pass through.  And I'm not even going to start on the black holes............................ x_x  But overall, yes. I do very much enjoy this game and recommend it to anyone else who shows even the slightest interest. It'll keep you busy for hours.

I bought this game during the autumn sale for a little over $2 and let me say it was a fantastic game. However, they are charming at times and the music score fits the environments really well.  In my opinion this concept of discovering the third dimension and rotating the space to access new areas was a really interesting and novel idea, and it was done very well. Also the codes in this game show just how much effort the developer put into this game, which to say is quite a lot. Although the controls could be a bit annoying at times, this game overall was fantastic, I am very happy I bought it, and have enjoyed every moment I spent playing it.  I would recommend this game to anyone looking to be challenged by some zany puzzles whilst having loads of fun.

a lot has been said about fez over the years. most people seem to have very strong opinions about it (and its creators). for me, it's one of my favorite games i've ever played. and i might never be able to finish it.  i'll start with the good: fez is visually breathtaking and immaculately designed. the level of polish and attention to detail is something i've rarely seen. everything about it exudes charm, cuteness, and fun. its game world is immense, sometimes to the point of being overwhelming, but it's so much fun to explore; there's so much variety, and so much mystery, that it never really gets boring or tedious. fez's puzzles are infamously complex and sometimes impenetrable - even once you've wrapped your head around navigating a 2d world in 3d, there's still a language and number system to decode, and even more than  that  if you plan on 100%ing the game. gomez, the player character, is a ♥♥♥♥ing adorable kirby-like example of simplistic, minimal character design made endearing and loveable. and of course there's also the soundtrack by disasterpeace, which perfectly suits the game's atmosphere and is incredibly well-made.   the bad: the controls are a bit stilted and can take some getting used to (especially jumping), which makes some simple exploration a bit harder than it should be at times. but that's not even the worst thing, really - fez, despite its polish, can be pretty buggy, from small weird visual glitches to massively gamebreaking issues. i had nearly 100%ed the game when i reached the ending, and was extremely disappointed to find that the game always crashes to my desktop just before the end of the final cutscene, meaning that, as long as i have this computer (or if someone magically fixes the issue somehow) i'll never be able to complete it. and that makes me really sad, because i love fez.  fez is perfect for those who sound of a cute, relaxing metroidvania with intricate lore and puzzle design. just make sure your computer will be able to run it properly.

This is a great game - screenshots and even video don't do it justice. I didn't really understand its greatness until I started to play. Changing perspectives to find your way forward is engaging enough and unique enough that none of the parts of my brain that indicate I'm solving a puzzle become engaged.   If I realize I'm being presented with a puzzle, I usually get irritated and turn a game off... I don't like having puzzles sprinkled into action, or platforming, or really anything other than an explicit puzzle game. The puzzles in this game are so naturally integrated, though, that I'm able to get the mental reward for solving them without feeling any of the exhaustion that comes with recognizing a puzzle. The only other hybrid-puzzle game I can think of that's been as successful at fooling me into enjoying it is Portal 2, which is pretty good company for an indie endeavor like this.  Fez is worth full price, and definitely worth it when on sale.

Maybe I had a little too much of expectation for this, but I can now say this game is full of missed opportunities. It is just sad. Recommendation? Screw it.

Absolutely beautiful and abstract game. Fez is a side-scroller / platforming/ puzzle game that takes place in 2 dimensional slices that can be altered by rotating the camera at 90 degree angles to alter the world. Such is similar to theory that imposes what four dimensions would be like relative to three dimensions. By altering your 2 dimensional world, you will solve very complicated plat-former puzzles to collect 3D cubes. This game is also nonlinear, allowing the player to roam wherever he or she pleases. I can't say any more about how much I love this game. I will cherish this game and perhaps in 20 years when this game looks like a retro piece of ♥♥♥♥, I will play through it again treating it as childhood nostalgia, even though I played it when I was in college.   Oh and I played this entire game high af, I would recommend it if you are high as well :3.

The dev's idea of a 2D creature's mentality is adorably similar to our theories about higher dimensions. One guy you talk to says, 'There's no such thing as a cube. Only squares.' Then, BOOM! Note: I did not start New Game+ will probably play it later.  Say what you will about Phil Phish, the man knows how to make a good puzzle based platformer. But the gameplay isn't what sticks out the most for me. It is the music and the way it works when you are rotating the level. I love that when you are rotating and you rotate yourself behind the wall the music becomes muffled. For me that is interesting and I am sure it has been done in other games, but I can't think of any right now.  The game controls great and you really only use the jump button, the left and right rotate buttons and the interact button primarily. It is a short game You could technically put it down after you collect 32 cubes. But to get the real ending you need to play through new game+ and collect ALL of the cubes (64 I believe).  The only downside in this for me was the map. because of the way it was design it could get confusing to tell where you could possibly go. The upside...there are two secret worlds, one is Gameboy influenced and the other is Virtual Boy influenced...really awesome, but the Virtual Boy world is hard as hell.  4/5

Other than Spelunky, FEZ is the only game I bought for more than one platform. I'm also aware that designer Phil Fish is a controversial figure. I'm enough of a cheapskate and activist that overcoming these things is a massive deal.  FEZ is beautiful and clever. Sometimes it's too clever for its own good, leading to some puzzles that are inexcusably ridiculous in some respect. Still, the high art and difficulty make this a must-play. It might even improve on a second playthrough, when you've forgotten enough to make it fun, but know enough to avoid the frustration of obscure puzzles.  Buy the soundtrack. It's honestly my favorite of all-time, and convinced me to fall in love again. It will capture your imagination.
This is by far the best side-scroller puzzle game I've ever played. Even though I got this during the summer sale, it's worth every penny at full price.

Don't let any 'drama' or hear-say regarding the creator, Phil Fish, sway your opinion: Fez is simply a fantastic game.  It starts out a beautifully composed, pixel-style platformer. From there, it blossoms into quite the relaxing, puzzling, exploration journey. My biggest recommendation: avoid as many spoilers as you can, at least through your first play-through. The more you discover on your own, the more you'll enjoy the experience.  Take your time with Fez, and you'll have an absolute blast. You can easily eek ten-plus hours from the game, depending on how many hints you look up. If you haven't played it yet, get on it. It's more than worth it.  Here's hoping that somehow, some way Fez II comes back one day...

For months I watched this game go on sale and each time I vowed that I would never buy it. How could another 8-bit style game be as good as everyone is claiming? I mean c'mon, a 91 on metacritic?!? Its just a lot of fun, super original concept, and more proof that you dont need advanced graphics or complicated gameplay to make create a wonderful title.

I'm actually kind of shocked how good this game is. I don't mean to say that I didn't expect it to be good--from all I'd heard (and from how much time and work went into it), I expected it to be pretty good. I just didn't expect to be as good as it was, nor to be able to really appreciate the game as much as I did.  I haven't really ever cared for puzzle games of any kind, but FEZ really grabbed me. By and large, it doesn't feel arbitrary nor, usually, too difficult, but it does require you to actually use your head. (Also, I went into it expecting to regularly be presented with puzzles that'd be nigh-impossible to figure out, based on comments I'd heard about it, but I found this a great exaggeration of the truth. Maybe that's just me going in with that impression, but if it isn't, don't be intimidated, it's not as bad/tough as everyone says.)  I could probably go on about this game for another few hundred words, but I'll refrain. This game is worth playing; play it.

For those of you who love platformer and puzzlers, this game is for you.  You start out as gomez, the main character who has the ability to change the 2d into 3d and flip the world, discovering a whole new area.  the objective throughout the game is to collect small cube bits to make a big cube, which is a piece of the gigantic cube, you do this through the game. Solving puzzles, some of which the community took a entire year to solve. Gameplay is fluent and addictive, keeping you coming back for more.  Warning: you will find yourself frustrated with some of the puzzles, it does take time and patience to solve many of them.  Although the incident with phil fish and fez two happened, it may keep some of you from playing it, but by all means. Just because the developer is a bag, don't stop playing it. The game is very fun and references do appear, secrets are there for you to solve, making the game mysterious.  anti cube puzzles: these are optional puzzles that appear throughout the game and are very difficult, you may get frustrated alot with these things.  There's a whole new language, you can decipher this by paying close attention and researching the wiki or any site.  Overall, I give fez a 8/10, I love platformers, as this gave me great nostalgia of the good old days of gaming. I recommend this to anyone who loves the genre. You will have great memories and fun playing this and solving puzzles on the wiki. Good luck.

This is a great game and one that deserves to be completed. That will require some perseverence and looking up hints and cheats online. And there's no shame in that. In fact, that would be in keeping with the idea of the game because there are one or two parts that are nearly impossible without looking for outside help. I won't spoil anything but you only complete the game thoroughly with game+ mode (continuing). The game changes some of the parameters and then you will have your 'Aha!' moments. I thoroughly completed the PSN version, later thoroughly completed the (original) Xbox 360 version. It's something I want to revisit, whatever my platform of choice.  While the game is good and full of love and joy for gaming history, the soundtrack from Disasterpeace is an absolute knockout. Listen to this game with headphones or a really good sound system! The soundtrack album is also available in digital download and I consider it the best video game sountrack album I have heard to date. The music is inspired by nostalgic chip-tune music but it goes in its own direction, using effects like wow to also harken back to music on worn film. The music can be joyous and exciting but also bittersweet and melancholic. It reminds me of the tone of Boards of Canada music.  I have completed this game thoroughly on Steam. I keep thinking of the game with fondness. It's not an ordinary game. Its theme is in praise of expanding one's knowledge and perspective of the world. The visual design, the gameplay methodology, and the music all come together to deliver that harmonious and edifying notion of coming out better than where you started.

FEZ is an amazing puzzle game that will warp your perception of the 2D and 3D plane. You play as a little white marshmellow and you have a fez, you need to save the world from dissapearing by collecting yellow popcorn. The soundtrack is second to none, on my phone even. The platforming is rewarding and doesn't punish faliure, yet acknowledges it. The puzzles at times can become so cryptic that you will want to quit, and thats understandable, but the game will always have you coming back.

When I first played FEZ, I thought it was alright, but it's just a 2D platformer on top of a 2D platformer. The mechanic for changing perspective between the different 2D worlds is not unlike that of better (older) titles, such as Paper Mario. While the game is not flawed by this similarity, it really has nothin more going for it.  The art style is a mix of retro 8 and 16 bit era gaming. If that's what you enjoy, then this may be a game for you. The screenshots really do show the game as-is.  Honestly, the end of the game is not as rewarding as one might hope. It lacks any true component of challenge. Whereas games like Stealth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or Mark of Ninja incorporate enemy elements alongside platforming, FEZ does not. I would have hoped for this challenge in FEZ 2, but the creator of the game apparently cannot take any criticism.  This is definitely a title for any gamer at any age, but it likely to be enjoyed more by a casual gamer.  I hope this was helpful.  6/10

While the story is linear and not too complex, after playing for a while I felt like I'm playing with just following the flow of the puzzles, not the story. But, the puzzles itself has is good enough to make this game one of my favorite puzzle game.  9/10

I'm still working out some of the last puzzles in Fez, one of which is why this game makes me feel the way it does.   I think it's because of all the mysteries this game cloaks itself in. Fez is an amazing game with beautiful scenery colors and gameplay. I have spent hours wandering the seemingly endless world that Fez takes place in. And not one of the minutes I spent in this game was wasted. The bright, vibrant colors combined with realistic shading and design combine to create an area I can explore for hours. First impression was amazing, really fun mechanics and gameplay, until you start having trouble finding more cubes. The goal of the game is to find 32 cubes (regular or anti-cubes), and eventually you 'will' have to resort to the internet. Those puzzles often require deciphering, invisible platforms, or other strange solutions where the hints are very easy to miss. Can be played until you can't solve any more puzzles without missing much; just play as much as you want.   + Fun mechanics + Easy controls (played with 360 controller, clearly designed with it in mind) + Beautiful graphics + Attention to detail, plenty of references, animals, etc + Short (took 6 hours for me), good for one weekend if you have a busy schedule + Essentially no dangers, pixel perfect movements, or randomly generated areas (very leisurely) - Some ridiculous puzzles, walkthrough necessary - No teleporting to visited areas, backtracking required (Teleporting back to start possible once you complete an area often available though) - Not very deep story (not expected) - Required windowed mode due to graphical bug (for me)

Fez is a 2D puzzle platformer that exists in a 3D world. The main mechanic is that you choose what 2D plane you move in, and is the source of most of the puzzles of fez. The main goal of Fez to explore the world to find as many cubes and anti-cubes as you can. There is no urgency in Fez, and it is a rather relaxing game.  The puzzles range that involve Fez's main mechanic are mostly interesting, but ususally are not all that hard. However, there are a lot of puzzles that involve code-breaking that start as fun but soon get repetitive. I think Fez can be frustrating for completionists, as some of the puzzles are very close to impossible to solve without looking them up online, which takes away some of the satisfaction. Seriously, to say that one needs to think outside of the box to solve the hardest puzzles in Fez is an incredible understatement. They will either have to be a lucky-guessing genius, or give up and find the solutions online.   A few other minor complaints: The in-game map is rather clunky. Additionally, while there are a few ways to travel quickly accross the large world of Fez, there will still be a large amount of backtracking that can get very tedious.   All in all, the game is relaxing and a fun game to throw some time into. There is a chance that completionists could end up finding Fez to get tedious after a while (I did, and gave up on completing Fez). But for anyone who has interest in a relaxing 2d puzzle platformer, I recommend this game.
Great game for people who like puzzles! The symbols are hard to figure out unless you look it up on the internet. Overall, I have to give it a 9.5 out of 10.

After finishing this game, my 4 year old turned to me and asked, 'What does that mean?' I don't have a clue.  This is a puzzle platformer whose gimmick is manipulating the perspective of the world. It's a really good gimmick and it works out well. During the course of the 6 hours I took playing and beating Fez I was constantly switching between really liking it and hating it. Obviously, that makes it hard to recommend.  There's a lot of content here. Much of it near impossible to access if you don't have a web-browser open with a walkthrough site telling you how to access the next secret cube. None of this is required to play and beat the game, but if you have the time and an open internet connection you can find out how to read the hidden language in the game, the unique counting system, the language for representing keypresses, etc. There's even a puzzle that requires you to decode morse code into the game language to find the right buttons to press. Does that make it a good game? Nope, not at all; but it does have a lot of content.  The travelling system is quite a pain. The problems arise when you know where you want to go (because you can see it on the map) but you can't get there easily, so you do a lot of back-tracking to get to there. Even worse is when you know where you want to go but can't find the door to get there. Then you start playing Russian roulette between loading screens hoping that this last door will be the one you need to get to.  Pretty much all my biggest problems with the game are easily solved with an active internet connection, but that's not as much fun. Sadly, being frustrated isn't fun either.  Still, the core concept is solid, the controls are spot on, and the world is colorful and vibrant. Pick it up if it's on sale and you've watched 'Indie Game: The Movie'

FEZ is a beautiful, aesthetically complete game that feels fresh while still maintaining a sense of familiarity.  The game has come under criticism for certain elements, particularly somewhat arduous navigation despite required backtracking, and some puzzles with questionable (or ambiguous, or nearly impossible) solutions, but these shortcomings are overshadowed by the beautiful colors, distinct but cohesive level design, engaging exploration and desire to advance.  My favorite part, however, is the sound design. Simple, elegant, minimalist. It sucks you in with its sparse but perfectly complimentary ambiance. I couldn't wait to put on a pair of headphones and just feel immersed in this pixelated world.  I recommend this game, but with a note of caution: if you can't figure something out, leave it and go explore somewhere else. Chances are you don't have what you need, and you'll only hurt your head by banging it against the wall.

Another thing I can say about FEZ is that despite its flaws (puzzles are either too simple or become too complex and boring to be worth the time, for instance), it's a great game.  I can't entirely pinpoint as to why I thought so, but I think those are part of the reason: - Low price of $9.99 - Long game - Beautiful - Nice soundtrack - Does take a gameplay element that is rarely seen and pushes it further (playing with perspective) - Many, many environments to explore at a nice pace  FEZ is not the groundbreaking game it could've been in my opinion, but the experience is definitely interesting and I don't doubt for an instant its worth your time and money, even if it was $14.99 or perhaps even slightly higher.

Great game! While playing, you can tell the amount of detail put into this game is astronomical and that the many delays of its release where well justified. Unlike any other game out there, Fez allows the player to 'flip' the screen view, much like turning a dice to see the numbers on the other sides. This feature adds depth to what would otherwise be just another side scroller adventure. At first glance, the game is relatively short, but allows for multiple playthroughs to find all collectibles. Fulfilling puzzles utilizing an in-game language replace the need for enemies and make the game hard to put down. The electronic style soundtrack adds to the experience and negates the need to have a background window open for music. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes their games to be a mental challange and not merely a first-person, action-filled shooter.

This charming, whimsical game takes pixel art retro-gaming into a fresh new dimension. Expect twisted perspectives as your world flattens and expands from 2D into 3D and back again with effects that would have made graphic artist M.C. Escher proud. Vector SFX graphics reach exalted heights, at times evocative of Doug Trumbull's time-travel sequence in Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey. Dreamy, spacious synthesized music, an air of mystery and plenty of secrets to uncover make the world of FEZ hard to escape and impossible to forget.

Extremely well put together game. Nearly perfect!   This is a 2d platforming game that allows 3d rotation of your viewable world. This relatively simple gimmick creates a wide variety of puzzle possibilities. Fez does a wonderful job of slowly introducing you to the mechanics, then expanding the goals for multiple hours of enjoyment.   I have a couple extremely minor complaints about the very end game unlockable goals, mostly they achieve unreasonable levels of difficulty (including a puzzle that literally nobody in the world has figured out WHY the solution is what it is).   Highly recommended!

Fez has a rich backstory, which you discover or more accurately decipher over the course of the game. The movement and rotation gameplay mechanics are great and the new twists which are added in the various sections of the map are fun rather than gimmicky. The puzzles get progressively more difficult after the first 32 Cubes are found, but in most of these cases the solutions are located in the game and provide a great sense of reward when finally figured out. Classrooms are a great place for learning!  The most difficult puzzles require understanding the three sets of symbols in the game. I ultimately had to look outside the game to figure the counting system, as I had actually made errors in my assumptions of how it worked! Nevertheless I thoroughly enjoyed playing Fez.

This game is entertaining, but wow am I lost. You play as a square-headed creature that realizes that he is a cube-head. Climb and spin the level in order to grab golden cubes and reach other areas. Most doors you go through send you to another area with many more doors. Some levels will come to an end, and then you will need to backtrack; some areas will have a portal cube that sends you to a slightly familiar level; and then others seem to go on for a very long time. I know that there are some areas that I have not explored because I chose the wrong door. I first started in a peaceful village, and now I'm in a floating graveyard; and I know I missed a treasure chest because I didn't have a key. I found a key ten levels later, but I forgot where the chest was located. Like I said, lost. This would be so much easier with a TARDIS.

Now stop reading this and go get Fez.     The Quick Brown Fox Jumps Over The Lazy Dog

One thing you may not know about Fez is that it has a LOT of puzzles. Most of them are very outside-of-the-box. Example: One time I had to use a QR code scanner to find a hidden collectible. I also keep a notebook and pencil ready when I play to solve some of the deeper mysteries. My experience with Fez has been very rejuvenating and satisfying.

It's a double edged sword. I highly recommend if you enjoy your platform games. It's cute, it's clever and allows all the freedom for you to just explore and get on with your adventure. Simple and provides plenty of jumping goodness. With it's instant checkpoint system, failing a jump isn't a crux which keeps the flow of moving continious.  However, i don't recommend if you hate cryptic bulls**t. This game notoriously has puzzles, although all are completely optional (you can complete the main game without worrying about it) which are incredibly vague. This game uses it's own language for you to decipher, binary to understand and even real-time clock puzzles to work out which will basically end up forcing you to go online instead to figure it out. I don't mind clever puzzles, but something that requires skill or logic puzzles. Puzzles which require to completely stop all momemtum, sit down, man the hell up and start reading and writing is the point that you think, 'F**k it'.   So, recommend for a platform fan, hard to recommend for completionists.

Amazing puzzle game! Main purpose is finding all the blocks and anti-blocks by a combination of classical 'jump & run' combined with quite a few puzzles (some of which are pretty myst style I dare say ;)).  However, do yourself a favor: don't cheat to resolve the puzzles. It is way more rewarding if you figure out the solution. Every puzzle can be solved by clues found in the game. I suggest preparing paper & pencil for deciphering some of the inscriptions. And don't be frustrated, to solve all puzzles you will _have_ to play the game twice (you won't loose puzzle progress after finishing the first time).  If you are really stuck, run a quick search on game exchange, they often given pointers to the solution without directly telling you.
If you like puzzles, and if you like mindbenders (ala portal) then this is your game.

Fez is probably the best single player game I have played in a long time. It encourages you to explore the beautiful world it provides, without making it an annoying task. The game looks beautiful and has good controls that allow you to maneuveur each stage however you see fit. The game is famous for its 2d 3d mechanic and it is executed flawlessly. Pros: Amazing art Good soundtrack Novel setting for a platformer  Cons: Boring puzzles Clues for puzzles must be found elsewhere Unrewarding and repetitive gameplay Little to none story  I got this game at 80% sale. The graphics alone was worth the price, therefore I recommend it.  This game gave me a feeling similar to that I had when I first played Minecraft. I explored the brand new world, collected shiny bits and enjoyed beautiful sights. If you are looking for some relaxing indie game, this one fills the role perfectly.  However this game has little to offer besides the beautiful world. The puzzles are either too simple or requires clues that must be found elsewhere. Without cool puzzles adding spice, gameplay is just traversing back and forth between stages hunting for bits.  What frustrated me most was totally obscure clues. Most of the time they feel like easter eggs rather than an integrated part of the game. They add some depth to the game but I honestly cannot appreciate the result. I will not comment in detail to avoid spoilers.  All in all, FEZ is a good platformer for its price. Don't expect much fun out of it though, and absolutely stay away if you are looking for mind blowing puzzles, as there is none.

I liked this game a lot, the multiple 2D perspective for puzzle solving is one of the most innovative things I've ever seen in gaming.  I wasn't able to finish though, because I myself am a compeltionist. I want to check every corner and make sure I don't miss anything, but thats not really possible in this game. Whenever I clear a room there will be multiple doors and each of those doors will lead to more doors and by the time I'm done following doors I'm caught in this huge network of levels. So when the game comes and says 'You have 16 blocks! go back to the block room to unlock a new door!' I spend almost an hour trying to find my way back to that room before I have to check a guide to get back. Any time that I need to stop a game and google for help is terrible for the flow of said game, but I think this might just be a personal issue I have and shoudn't reflect the quality of the game.  The game itself is wonderful and I'd recommend it to anyone just to have them experiance the unique perspective of FEZ.

Creative puzzle platformer with great soundtrack. Fez deserves the 10+ hours of a puzzle-solver's time.  On a two-dimensional screen, rotate the world to access the third dimension, which gives access to more parts of the level. Great concept and it is implemented well. The game demands more skill in puzzle-solving than in platforming. It's not meant to be 100% completed in one playthrough; in New Game+, the player gets an ability to find more clues to solving the puzzles.  The puzzles constitute most of the game, and although it's possible to get lucky in solving them, the solutions definitely have strong reasoning behind them. The mechanics and clues behind the puzzles are among the most creative that I have seen.

Dang, this is hard. So good, but seriously hard.  If you are into cryptography and love serious challenges, get this. While I was able to figure out enough to 'beat the game' i.e. get to the credit sequence, I know for a fact that never in my life will I be able to 100% this game. I heard somewhere a great comparison: 'The hard puzzles in Portal 2 are real thinkers. You will sit back in your chair and think, 'how is this possible?', but 10 minutes later you will have solved the puzzle and be moving on. The hard puzzles in Fez take 10 hours and a doctrate in mathematics.' That wasn't the exact quote, but it gives you the idea. The hard puzzles are hard as hell. Throughout the game there are two 'languages' tha you will encounter that you have to break to continue. The first is fairly simple (I got it after only about 4 hours of fiddling around) and the other is just insane. Maybe I am missing somthing, but wow.  Gameplay itself is fantastic. Super unique concept, being a 2D person in a 3D world, and it takes a bit to really wrap your mind aroud it. The map you have is also quite challenging to understand at first, but trust me you can get the hang of it.  Tons of really intriguing puzzles all in one box. Some easy, some borderline impossible. Smooth gameplay, excellent concept.  Solid A+ game. Took me about 7 hours to get to the credit sequence (but completing probably half the puzzles, total).

Unique and fun game. Very big game for the price. Some puzzles required extensive effort and time so I looked up the answers so I could move forward with more casual game play. I don't feel that doing so detracted from my enjoyment of the game.

Self indulgent and underrealized.  Fez is dominated by a main puzzle mechanic that is never used to any real effect, frustrating platforming physics, almost no variation in mechanics, and 'decode the background' puzzles. In addition, it makes frequent use of artless metagame effects (e.g. fake crashes) that are clearly supposed to affect the player but in reality the only emotion they evoke is impatience.  The central gimmick of the game is that you interact with a 2D plane, but the world is 3D and can be rotated. By switching the world around, you can change the apparent location of objects and move between them even if they're at wildly different depths. Nearly every actual use of this mechanic will be fully explored by the time you finish the tutorial. Nearly all the rest of the game makes use of the same two or three tricks.  World locations have their own additional mechanic layered on top of the basic platforming, but none are more complex than basic key/door puzzles. You might have to carry a block to a switch, carry a bomb to a cracked wall, or raise a platform into position, but never will you have to engage in any real thought or foresight about your actions.  Further frustrating the samey gameplay are the core platforming actions you'll be engaging in for the entire game. Your character is slow and heavy. Changing direction is a chore and it takes ages to traverse platforms. The climbing and mantling animations are even slower, giving you plenty of time to reflect on exactly how long it takes for your inputs to be realized into actual events.  And then there are the optional anticube puzzles. And thank God they're optional. I found two that required me to scan a QR code. I do not own a smart phone. Another needed me to feel the vibrations in my controller and copy the left/right pattern as world rotations. I can't imagine what I would've done if weren't using an Xbox controller. Probably give up and go somewhere else. Plenty of other apparent puzzles had no immediate means of interaction, and on my save they are still unsolved. I have little desire to go back and try them again.  As a fan of indie games, I hate Fez for being everything people think of when they say 'Ugh, indie games.' Thanks for living up to the stereotype, Phil Fish.

Fez is secretly two games.  One of those games is a mediocre puzzle-platformer, where you rotate your view to 'move' platforms around and do a couple other gimmicky things with the ability. In particular, getting around the map is a complete chore, even with the assorted teleporters floating around.  The other game is a series of obscure hidden riddles, one of which was so fiendish the community had to solve it by brute force rather than by 'solving' the puzzle. Like many collections of riddles, it is completely and utterly trivialised by modern conveniences like Wikis and GameFAQs. The solutions are typically controller codes you punch in to receive your prize.  Neither game I think is very good.

This is a tricky game for me to rate. I'm somewhere between Yes and No on is.  One one hand the concept of these changing perspectives is great and allows for some amazing puzzles.  But on the other hand the game is very frustrating. Relying on code alphabets, tetris code, being in the right place during the right ingame time and an great deal of backtracking through a maze that's very hard to navigate.  Unless you enjoy pointless busyword in translating the messages, know what tetris code is and willing to dig up other obsure puzzle solutions OR willing to make frequent trips to help sites then Fez is most likey going to frustrate you to no end after the early 30%.  In my book this is a flawed gem. It could have (and at times IS) amazing but wastes it's potential with too much unenjoyable 'work' to progress.

I really tried to like this game but I managed to stand it 2 hours and I'll give up, because the game is just not fun.  The whole game is about collect cubes... and more cubes... oh can't reach, switch dimension... collect more cubes.... zzz...  The dialogs are poor and the story is almost nonexisting.  The game seems to have 'borrowed' lots of elements from Super Paper Mario like the void which is expanding and puzzle like level design to be solved by switching dimensions... It would be unfair to compare FEZ to Super Paper Mario as there is a quite reasonable budget difference (although the world design and graphics are really professional)  But the fact that the only thing which you do is collecting those darn cubes without any combat makes the game terribly repetitive.  So if you're expecting a good platformer game don't buy this game However if you're into exploration games and don't have any expectations for a good story or good dialogs then this is your game. Fez is beautiful to look at and the premise of the game had us all hyped. Overhyped. I badly wanted to enjoy Fez, believing that it would inspire developers in the future to think more creatively with their mechanics designs. Instead, I found the core gameplay, the entire appeal of the game, to be highly disappointing.   After the first couple hours of gameplay, you soon realize that all the puzzles are copies of each other arranged slightly differently and generally boils down to the player rotating the camera 378629 times (this along with the bright colour palette left me feeling sick after a while) until seeing the solution rather than solving thinking exercises.   The konami and QR codes had absolutely nothing to add to the gameplay and didn't even loosely tie into the story. Personally, I just found those 'puzzles' a hindrance. The game gives little to no hints of how to solve puzzles and often become arbitrary because of this. However, puzzles are linked to each other which means that there is a A LOT of backtracking. (Did I mention that there's no fast travel?) With the leisurely pace Gomez (you) keep throughout the game, this is not a game for the impatient.
Game mechanics are very interesting, but Phil, the game itself is mediocre, I expected more. Music is poor and anoying, and the game gets boring after an hour.

FEZ is a game which clearly has had a huge amount of time spent on the vast number of levels (each obviously carefully crafted), the perfectly judged tone (both surface and deeper), and apparently the deeper challenges.  I say apparently in that last clause because, despite this effort, the core platforming gameplay just isn't 'fun' enough to support all the running around and backtracking you apparently need to do to actually explore the deeper levels of the game. After 3 hours of platforming around, I'm just not having enough fun getting from place to place (and there's lots of places to get to) for me to put up with that necessary input in order to access the deeper levels.   Sad to say, FEZ is a game where the primary mechanic lets down all of the things hanging off of it.

This game is for masochists, but you can't tell that right away. Oh no, it entices you with its cute graphics and adorable fez-sporting hero, Gomez, who lives in a 2D world which suddenly opens up to him when a whole new third dimension is revealed. He goes on to explore it and solve various puzzles along the way.  Some of the puzzles are easy, but the further you progress, the more difficult they get, and honestly, some of them are simply unfair in that they are nearly impossible to solve using normal methods - some were only solved by gamers via brute-forcing (or knowing the answer in advance and trying to find a solution that resulted in it). This is not acceptable for me in a puzzle game and only serves to frustrate and anger... and waste a ton of time. Unsolvable puzzles scream bad design to me. Moreover, there are a few QR codes that you have to scan throughout the game, giving you easy answers to otherwise much more complicated puzzles... unless, of course, you cannot scan them, which was what happened in my case - my phone simply refused to recognise them (perhaps the contrast was too low, as QR codes are meant to be black and white, not light purple and slightly darker purple).   As such, I can only recommend this game to people who enjoy the dissatisfaction of NOT winning the game entirely through their own efforts. While the price (especially when on sale) is very reasonable, it's just too painful a gaming experience - I expected enjoyment when I bought it and got rather less of it than I hoped for!

Only get it on sale, and only for the 'easy' puzzles (yellow cubes) which require what you'd expect: navigate an area while spinning between perspectives, making things line up in interesting ways. You can get the 'easy' ending playing only these.  The other half of the game (blue cubes) is Myst-style puzzles so tedious and obtuse that it's a question of whether you get 25% of them vs. 75%, depending on how much effort you put in. No one gets them all. More importantly  there are no room names , so when you try a puzzle for an appropriate amount of time and want to move on -- too bad. There's no way to look up an answer for just that puzzle. You either read a full-spoiler guide, or quit the game. And do you really want to do puzzles that involve transcribing glyphs from 3 made-up alphabets, scanning QR codes with a smartphone, and keeping it all written down to cross-reference later? Is that what anyone thinks Fez is going to be about when they buy it?  Worst of all: backtracking. A lot of areas look just like others, and some have 8 doors which look like all the other doors. And no room names! Good luck remembering how you got from there to here, never mind finding your way back later. It gets old really fast.

I wouldn't call Fez' perspective shifting a gimmick as it is a decently well thought out mechanic IMO. Unfortunately what frustrated me most about this game is that it's effectively a platformer with lots of slow backtracking necessary to figure out a few unintuitive puzzles. I never felt like I was progressing in any way other than slowly gaining arbitrary cubes. If I'm expected to wander through a 2d world (slowly), then I want to feel confident that I am better armed to figure out the significance of a seemingly empty room. In Metroid games you get new powers that are the keys to previously unsolvable puzzles. In this game the keys to any puzzle you can't figure out might just be to tediously study the pixel art in a level across the game world. Alternatively you can look up the answer on youtube and feel cheated that the game expected x level of attention for a 'casual platformer'. It's a cool game to try and a boring game to try to finish.
